verses.text: See! The LORD is emptying the earth and making it desolate; he twists its surface and scatters its inhabitants.
verses.comment: God's sovereign judgment upon the whole earth is being declared, reminiscent of the flood in Noah's time. This marks a reversal of creation, highlighting God's authority over the world.

verses.text: And it will be, as with the people, so with the priest; as with the servant, so with his master; as with the maid, so with her mistress; as with the buyer, so with the seller; as with the lender, so with the borrower; as with the creditor, so with the debtor.
verses.comment: This verse shows that no one will be exempt from God’s judgment, regardless of social or religious status, a theme repeated throughout scripture.

verses.text: The earth will be completely emptied and utterly plundered, for the LORD has spoken this word.
verses.comment: The emphatic language underscores both the severity and certainty of God’s judgment, as His word never fails.

verses.text: The earth mourns and withers, the world languishes and fades away; the exalted people of the earth languish.
verses.comment: The consequences of human sin are cosmic, affecting both creation and humanity. Romans 8:22 echoes this, 'the whole creation groans,' reminding us that mankind’s fate is bound to the world.

verses.text: The earth is defiled by its inhabitants, for they have transgressed the laws, violated the statutes, broken the everlasting covenant.
verses.comment: Isaiah refers to a covenant that reaches back to Noah and Adam, emphasizing humanity’s responsibility for universal sin. Breaking of the everlasting covenant points to a foundational tradition connecting the old and new covenants.

verses.text: Therefore, a curse devours the earth, and those who dwell in it bear the guilt; therefore the inhabitants of the earth are burned, and few people are left.
verses.comment: A curse as a punishment for breaking covenant recalls Adam and Eve being expelled from Eden (Gen. 3:17–19). Only a remnant will survive, a recurring scriptural theme.

verses.text: The new wine dries up, the vine withers, all the merrymakers groan.
verses.comment: The cessation of wine and joy signals the removal of God’s blessing, prefiguring spiritual desolation that only true communion can restore.

verses.text: The mirth of tambourines is silenced, the noise of those exulting stops, the joy of the harp ceases.
verses.comment: Music and celebration, once connected to worship and feasts (Ps. 150), are brought to an end because of separation from God.

verses.text: They do not drink wine with a song; strong drink is bitter to those who drink it.
verses.comment: Even that which once brought joy now brings bitterness—sin corrupts even natural pleasures.

verses.text: The city of chaos is broken down; every house is shut so that no one can enter.
verses.comment: The 'city of chaos' symbolizes humanity in opposition to God; all that was built on sin and pride collapses, foreshadowing the ultimate destruction of Babylon (Revelation 18).

verses.text: There is a cry for wine in the streets; all joy grows dark; the gladness of the earth is banished.
verses.comment: Joy is banished as a consequence of sin, contrasting with the joy found in God’s presence (Ps. 16:11).

verses.text: Desolation remains in the city, and the gate is battered to ruins.
verses.comment: Physical destruction reflects spiritual decay—inside and outside, ruin results from turning away from God.

verses.text: For thus it will be in the midst of the earth among the peoples, as the shaking of an olive tree, as the gleanings when the grape harvest is done.
verses.comment: A small remnant will be left, like olives or grapes remaining after the harvest—pointing to God’s faithfulness to preserve a faithful remnant.

verses.text: They lift up their voices, they sing for joy; over the majesty of the LORD they shout from the west.
verses.comment: Even in judgment, hope remains for the faithful who still worship God. This foreshadows the inclusion of all nations in the true worship of the LORD.

verses.text: Therefore in the east give glory to the LORD; in the coastlands of the sea, to the name of the LORD, the God of Israel.
verses.comment: True worship is called for in all lands, not just Israel, showing God’s universal reign and the gathering of many into one faith.

verses.text: From the ends of the earth we hear songs: 'Glory to the Righteous One!' But I say, 'I waste away, I waste away! Woe to me! For traitors betray—with betrayal the traitors betray.'
verses.comment: The faithful around the world praise God, but Isaiah laments betrayal and sin, resembling the tension between suffering and glory seen in the life of Christ (Heb. 5:7–9).

verses.text: Terror, the pit, and the snare are upon you, O inhabitant of the earth.
verses.comment: The triple threat symbolizes inescapable judgment, a frequent prophetic warning.

verses.text: Whoever flees at the sound of terror will fall into the pit, and he who climbs out of the pit will be caught in the snare; for the windows of heaven are opened, and the foundations of the earth tremble.
verses.comment: This echoes the language of the flood (Gen. 7)—judgment is inescapable, emphasizing the seriousness of sin.

verses.text: The earth is utterly broken, the earth is violently shaken, the earth is thoroughly shaken.
verses.comment: The repeated emphasis points to the totality of judgment. This kind of cosmic shaking is found in apocalyptic literature, foreshadowing final judgment and renewal.

verses.text: The earth staggers like a drunkard, sways like a hut in the wind; its transgression weighs heavy upon it, and it falls and will not rise again.
verses.comment: Sin has destabilized creation itself. The finality echoes themes of irrevocable judgment seen in Revelation.

verses.text: On that day the LORD will punish the host of heaven above and the kings of the earth below.
verses.comment: All spiritual powers and earthly rulers are held accountable by God—pointing toward the final subjection of all things to Christ.

verses.text: They will be gathered together, like prisoners in a pit; they will be shut up in a prison, and after many days they will be punished.
verses.comment: This foreshadows the final judgment, where evil will be confined and punished—anticipating eschatological themes of the New Testament.

verses.text: Then the moon will be confounded and the sun ashamed, for the LORD of hosts will reign on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem, and before his elders, glory will shine.
verses.comment: God’s glory will surpass even the sun and moon, as He reigns from Zion. The reference to 'elders' points to a council gathered around God's throne (Rev. 4:4)—prefiguring the heavenly liturgy and worship of the eternal King.
